    • Method Detail

      • getClock

        public static VectorClock getClock(int... nodes)
        Get a vector clock with events on the sequence of nodes given So getClock(1,1,2,2,2) means a clock that has two writes on node 1 and 3 writes on node 2. The timestamp will be the current time
        Parameters:
        nodes - The sequence of nodes
        Returns:
        A VectorClock initialized with the given sequence of events

      • getClockT

        public static VectorClock getClockT(long timestamp,
                    int... nodes)
        Get a vector clock with a the given timestamp and events on the sequence of nodes given So getClock(1,1,2,2,2) means a clock that has two writes on node 1 and 3 writes on node 2.
        Parameters:
        nodes - The sequence of nodes
        Returns:
        A VectorClock initialized with the given sequence of events

      • incrementT

        public static VectorClock incrementT(long timestamp,
                     VectorClock clock,
                     int... nodes)
        Record events for the given sequence of nodes
        Parameters:
        clock - The VectorClock to record the events on
        nodes - The sequences of node events

        public static VectorClock increment(VectorClock clock,

        Record events for the given sequence of nodes
        Parameters:

        nodes - The sequences of node events

      • bytesEqual

        public static boolean bytesEqual(byte[] a1,
                 byte[] a2)
        Test two byte arrays for (deep) equality. I think this exists in java 6 but not java 5
        Parameters:
        a1 - Array 1
        a2 - Array 2
        Returns:
        True iff a1.length == a2.length and a1[i] == a2[i] for 0 <= i < a1.length

      • randomInts

        public static int[] randomInts(int max,
               int count)
        Return an array of length count containing random integers in the range (0, max) generated off the test rng.
        Parameters:
        max - The bound on the random number size
        count - The number of integers to generate
        Returns:
        The array of integers

      • shuffle

        public static int[] shuffle(int[] input)
        Weirdly java doesn't seem to have Arrays.shuffle(), this terrible hack does that.
        Returns:
        A shuffled copy of the input
